pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:0.4: 6. The training rule on building huts
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrel sanctuary.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.2: At that time the monks of Āḷavī were building huts by means of begging. The huts were intended for themselves, did not have a sponsoring owner, and were inappropriately large.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.3: And since they were never finished,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.4: the monks kept on begging and asking,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.5: “Please give a man, a servant, an ox, a cart, a machete, a hatchet, an ax, a spade, a chisel; give creepers, bamboo, reeds, grass, clay.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.6: People felt oppressed by all the begging and asking, so much so that when they saw a monk they became alarmed and fearful. They turned away, took a different path, ran off, and closed their doors.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.7: They even ran away when they saw cows, thinking they were monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.8: Just then Venerable Mahākassapa, after completing the rainy-season residence at Rājagaha, set out for Āḷavī.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.10: he stayed at the Aggāḷava Shrine.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.11: One morning Venerable Mahākassapa robed up, took his bowl and robe, and entered Āḷavī for alms.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.12: When people saw him, they became alarmed and fearful. They turned away, took a different path, ran off, and closed their doors.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.13: After finishing his almsround and eating his meal, Venerable Mahākassapa returned and said to the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.14: “There used to be plenty of almsfood in Āḷavī, and it was easy to get by on alms.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.15: But now there’s a shortage, and it’s hard to get by.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.17: The monks told Venerable Mahākassapa what had happened.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.1: Soon afterwards the Buddha too set out wandering toward Āḷavī after staying at Rājagaha for as long as he liked.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.3: he too stayed at the Aggāḷava Shrine.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.4: Venerable Mahākassapa then went to see the Buddha, bowed, sat down,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.5: and told him what had happened.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.6: The Buddha had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks of Āḷavī:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.7: “Is it true, monks, that this is happening?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.14: “Foolish men, how can you act like this?
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.19: After rebuking them, he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.1: “Once upon a time, monks, two sages who were brothers lived near the river Ganges.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.2: On one occasion the dragon king Maṇikaṇṭha emerged from the Ganges and went up to the younger sage. He encircled him with seven coils and spread his large hood over his head.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.3: Then, because of his fear of that dragon, the younger sage became thin, haggard, and pale, with veins protruding all over his body.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.4: The older sage saw him like this
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.5: and asked him what was the matter.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.9: The elder sage said, ‘So, do you want that dragon to stay away?’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.11: ‘Well then, did you see anything belonging to that dragon?’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.12: ‘I saw an ornamental gem on his neck.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.13: ‘In that case, ask the dragon for that gem.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.16: Soon the dragon king again emerged from the Ganges and went up to the younger sage.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.17: And the sage said to him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.21: ‘The monk is asking for the gem; he wants the gem,’ and he left in a hurry.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.22: Once more the dragon king emerged from the Ganges and approached the younger sage.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.29: Yet again the dragon king emerged from the Ganges.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.30: The younger sage saw him emerging
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.34: The dragon king then spoke these verses to the sage:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.35: ‘My food and drink are abundant and sublime,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.36: And they appear because of this gem.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.37: I won’t give it to you—you ask too much—
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.38: Nor will I return to your hermitage.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.39: Like a youth holding a sword polished on a rock,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.40: You frighten me, asking for this gem.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.41: I won’t give it to you—you ask too much—
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.42: Nor will I return to your hermitage.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.43: And the dragon king Maṇikaṇṭha thought,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.44: ‘The monk is asking for the gem; he wants the gem,’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.45: and he left and never returned.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.46: Because he did not get to see that beautiful dragon, the young sage became even thinner, more haggard and pale, his veins protruding even more.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.47: The older sage saw him like this
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.48: and asked what was the matter.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.50: He replied, ‘It’s because I no longer get to see that beautiful dragon.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.51: The older sage then spoke to him in verse:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.52: ‘One shouldn’t beg from those one wishes to be dear to;
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.53: One is detested for asking for too much.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.54: When the brahmin asked the dragon for his gem,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.55: It left and was never to be seen again.’

pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.1: “At one time, monks, a certain monk lived in a forest grove on the slopes of the Himalayas.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.2: Not far from that grove was a large, low-lying marsh.

pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.9: ‘I’m keeping well, Sir, I’m getting by.

pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.15: I left because I was disturbed by the noise of that flock of birds.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.16: ‘Do you want that flock of birds to stay away?’

pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.20: I want a feather from anyone roosting in this forest grove.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.21: Each one of you must give me a feather.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.23: and last part of the night do the same thing.’

pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.5: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.6.1: ‘When a monk, by means of begging, builds a hut without a sponsoring owner and intended for himself, it is to be no more than twelve standard handspans long and seven wide inside.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.7: He must have monks approve a site where no harm will be done and which has space on all sides.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.8: If a monk, by means of begging, builds a hut on a site where harm will be done and which lacks space on all sides, or he does not have monks approve the site, or he exceeds the right size, he commits an offense entailing suspension.’”
